prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not going to my best friends wedding.
So my best friend (lets call her G) has decided to have her wedding, that's awesome and I'm happy she found the one. 

The issue is G never sent out save the dates, meaning last week we got the actual wedding invitations for a wedding that is happening in 1 month.  

It will be at her grandmother's Ranch and it seems like a pretty nice wedding. 

here is where the issue started. 

a few months ago me and 3 friends decided to plan a trip to Australia to backpack/sightsee for 2 weeks, the trip starts 2 days before the wedding so we can't go. G knew about the trip as we invited her but I'm geussing she forgot. 
she is mad at all of us for not just cancelling the trip and being at her wedding. 

all of us are not super rich so this would be a huge loss if we cancelled the trip. (so we are not) 

I also want to add that she invited 50 people, I asked. and only 20 can make it as she gave 1 month notice. 

she is flipping her shit and acting like we should drop everything for her. 

AITA for not just cancelling my 2 week trip to go to her wedding? 
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's tackle this question. The user is asking if the author of the AITA scenario is in the wrong for not attending their best friend's wedding. Let me break down the details.

First, the friend (G) didn't send a save-the-date, only the actual invitations a month before the wedding. That's pretty short notice, especially for an international trip. The author and their friends had planned a trip to Australia, which had already been organized. They invited G to the trip, but she forgot about it. Now she's upset because they can't cancel their trip, which is a big financial hit for them. The author and friends aren't wealthy, and only 20 out of 50 invited people can attend because of the short notice.

So, who's at fault here? G didn't communicate properly by not sending a save-the-date. She knew about the trip but didn't remember, which is on her. The author's group had planned this trip in advance and can't just drop it without significant loss. The fact that many others also can't attend (only 20 out of 50) suggests that the short notice is the main issue. 

I think the author isn't in the wrong because they made their plans known and the wedding date was announced too late. G should have given more notice, and expecting others to cancel a trip they've already planned isn't fair. The answer should be B.
